awd_titl_txt: Mechanisms of Lipid Import into Chloroplasts
awd_abstract_narration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT 
The chloroplast is the defining organelle of plant cells. It contains the photosynthetic membrane, which converts sunlight into chemical energy, a process essential to most forms of life on earth. The photosynthetic membrane is not able to make its building blocks, the polar lipid constituents, but relies on lipid precursors assembled at the inner and outer chloroplast envelope membranes and the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), a membrane system outside the chloroplast. Therefore, lipid transfer into the chloroplast and through the envelope membranes to the photosynthetic membranes is essential. Gaining a mechanistic understanding of lipid transfer processes involved in the assembly of the photosynthetic membrane is the long-term goal of this project.

The isolation of genetic mutants of the model plant Arabidopsis disrupted in ER-to-chloroplast lipid transfer has enabled first mechanistic studies of the underlying phenomena.  The tgd mutants of Arabidopsis are disrupted in chloroplast lipid import and are named for their characteristic phenotype, the accumulation of the oligogalactolipid trigalactosyldiacylglycerol. Availability of these mutants led to the identification of four key proteins (TGD1,2,3,4) involved in the process. TGD1, 2 and 3 resemble components of ATP Binding Cassette (ABC) transporters and are hypothesized to assemble into a complex that facilitates transfer of lipids between the chloroplast envelope membranes and through the inner envelope membrane. The TGD4 protein on the other hand is integrated in the chloroplast outer envelope membrane and is hypothesized to transfer lipids from the ER to the TGD1,2,3 complex. This project will investigate how TGD4 and TGD1,2,3 complexes assemble and form a lipid conduit from the ER through the chloroplast envelope membranes, an essential feature of chloroplast membrane biogenesis.

BROADER IMPACTS 
Mechanisms of interorganelle lipid transfer in any eukaryotic cell are poorly understood but essential to organelle formation. Thus, it is expected that the analysis of chloroplast lipid import will provide mechanistic insights into general lipid transfer phenomena relevant beyond plant cells.  The project also provides excellent training opportunities for a postdoctoral researcher, a graduate student, and undergraduate student, who collaborate effectively in a team. Elements of the project are specifically designed for the participation of undergraduate students, and will provide training in basic laboratory techniques in molecular biology and biochemistry and require critical thinking towards proper experimental controls and data analysis. All participants including the undergraduate students present their results in weekly lab meetings, present posters or talks at scientific meetings, and participate in the publication of the results as coauthors. All coauthors actively participate in manuscript writing. Co-mentoring of the graduate and undergraduate students by the postdoctoral researcher provides experience in the management of people and projects. In addition, undergraduate students working on the project participate in a summer training program in Plant Genomics at Michigan State University. This program has successfully recruited a diverse group of students and faculty in the past five years.

Intellectual Merit. Plants convert solar energy into chemical energy through the process of photosynthesis. Plant photosynthesis is a function of the photosynthetic membrane inside chloroplasts. This membrane consists of the photosynthetic protein-pigment complexes embedded into a specific lipid matrix. In plant cells, two compartments cooperate in the biosynthesis of these lipids, the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and the chloroplast. As a consequence, lipid precursors have to be imported from the ER into the chloroplast. In the model plant Arabidopsis and all other plants studied, at least four proteins are involved in lipid import into chloroplasts and are designated TriGalactosylDiacylglycerol (TGD) 1, 2, 3, 4 after the accumulation of the namesake lipid in the respective mutants. Loss of any of these proteins leads to severe impairment of growth or even embryo-lethality showing the essential role these proteins, and by extrapolation lipid import into chloroplasts in general, play in plants. The project encompassed the functional analysis of these proteins in the model plant, Arabidopsis, and the model green alga, Chlamydomonas, leading to a number findings advancing the field. TGD1, 2, and 3 constitute a multipartite ABC transporter in the inner chloroplast envelope membrane, and TGD4 forms a complex in the outer chloroplast envelope membrane. The ABC transporter is unusual as the presumptive substrate binding protein, TGD2, occurs in 8-12 copies in this complex, while TGD1 and TGD3 are present in two copies. The TGD2 and TGD4 proteins specifically bind phosphatidic acid. Multiple approaches to reconstitute the complex or test its transport function in isolated chloroplast or isolated envelope membranes failed to demonstrate that phosphatidic acid is actually the transported lipid. To address the question of the transported lipid species in a completely different way and to observe lipid trafficking directly in the plant itself, a synthetic biology approach has been developed. By introducing a foreign fatty acid desaturase associated with the ER, specific fatty acids new to Arabidopsis are introduced into ER-derived lipid precursors. The appearance of these fatty acids in chloroplast lipids was observed and provides a measure for lipid import into chloroplasts. When this approach was applied to the tgd mutants, it permitted the modeling of lipid flux into the chloroplast and indirectly provided insights into the role the TGD proteins play in this process. Aside from demonstrating that this approach works by recapitulating findings made using conventional lipid analysis of the tgd mutants, new and unexpected insights have been gained, such as clear evidence for the import of precursors for phosphatidylglycerol biosynthesis from the ER. The full potential of this approach has not yet been reached and continuing efforts promise to lead to further insights into chloroplast lipid import in plants in the near future. Through the identification of a TGD2 loss-of-function mutant in the green alga Chlamydomonas, it was possible to show the function of the TGD1, 2, 3 ABC transporter complex in chloroplast lipid import in algae. This is of interest here because this alga lacks phosphatidylcholine, one of the proposed chloroplast imported lipids in plants, and because ER to chloroplast lipid trafficking was thought to be nonexistent in Chlamydomonas based on lipid profiling data.

Aside from disseminating the findings of this work in peer reviewed publications and public presentations at scientific meetings by all project participants, training and mentoring opportunities were provided for one postdoc, three graduate and five undergraduate students.
